words.def: A measure of how much amount of water a fabric can absorb.
words.name: Absorbency

words.def: Acetate is a synthetic fiber.
words.name: Acetate

words.def: Acrylic fiber is a synthetic polymer fiber that contains at least 85% acrylonitrile.
words.name: Acrylic

words.def: Aida cloth is a coarse open-weave fabric traditionally used for cross-stitch.
words.name: Aida cloth

words.def: Alnage is the official supervision of the shape and quality of manufactured woolen cloth.
words.name: Alnage

words.def:
Alpaca is a name given to two distinct things:

The wool of the Peruvian alpaca.
A style of fabric originally made from alpaca fiber but now frequently made from a similar type of fiber.
words.name: Alpaca

words.def: Angora refers to the hair of the Angora rabbit, or the fabric made from Angora rabbit fur. (Fabric made from angora goat is mohair.)[1]
words.name: Angora

words.def: Appliqué is a sewing technique in which fabric shapes, lace or trim, are sewn onto a foundation fabric to create designs.[2]
words.name: Appliqué

words.def: Aramid fiber is a fire-resistant and strong synthetic fiber.
words.name: Aramid

words.def: An argyle pattern is one containing diamonds in a sort of diagonal checkerboard pattern.
words.name: Argyle

words.def: Backstrap looms, as the name implies, are tied around the weaver's waist on one end and around a stationary object such as a tree, post, or door on the other. Tension can be adjusted simply by leaning back. Backstrap looms are very portable, since they can simply be rolled up and carried.
words.name: Backstrap loom

words.def: Baize is a coarse woollen or cotton cloth, often coloured red or green.
words.name: Baize

words.def: Ballistic nylon is a thick, tough synthetic fabric used for a variety of applications.
words.name: Ballistic nylon

words.def: Barathea is an indistinct twill or broken rib - usually a twilled hopsack weave - with a fine textured, slightly pebbled surface. Often of silk or silk blended with wool, used for neckties, women's fine suits and coats, men's and women's evening wear.
words.name: Barathea

words.def: Batik is an Indonesian traditional word and refers to a generic wax-resist dyeing technique used on fabric.
words.name: Batik

words.def: Bedford cord is a combination of two kinds of weave, namely plain and drill. It is a durable fabric that is often used in upholstery or outerwear.
words.name: Bedford cord

words.def: The bias direction of a piece of woven fabric, usually referred to simply as "the bias", is at 45 degrees to its warp and weft threads. Every piece of woven fabric has two biases, perpendicular to each other.
words.name: Bias

words.def: In sewing, binding is used as both a noun and a verb to refer to finishing a seam or hem of a garment, usually by rolling or pressing then stitching on an edging or trim.
words.name: Binding

words.def: A blend is a fabric or yarn made up of more than one type of fiber.
words.name: Blend

words.def: Bobbin lace is a delicate lace that uses wound spools of thread (the bobbins) to weave together the shapes in the lace.
words.name: Bobbin lace

words.def: Bobbinet is a tulle netting with hexagonal shaped holes, traditionally used as a base for embroidery and lingerie.
words.name: Bobbinet

words.def: Bombazine is a fabric originally made of silk or silk and wool, and now also made of cotton and wool or of wool alone. It is twilled or corded and used for dress-material.
words.name: Bombazine

words.def: To braid is to interweave or twine three or more separate strands of one or more materials in a diagonally overlapping pattern.
words.name: Braid

words.def: Material of superior quality.
words.name: Broadcloth

words.def: Forming patterns in cloth with a supplementary weft.
words.name: Brocade

words.def: Buckram is a stiff cloth, made of cotton or linen, which is used to cover, and protect, a book, and although more expensive than its lookalike, Brella, is stronger and resistant to cockroaches eating it. Buckram can also be used to stiffen clothes.
words.name: Buckram

words.def: Burlap is a type of cloth often used for sacks.
words.name: Burlap

words.def: Calico is a type of fabric made from unbleached, and often not fully processed, cotton. Also referred to a type of Printing.
words.name: Calico

words.def: Cambric is a lightweight cotton cloth used as fabric for lace and needlework.
words.name: Cambric

words.def: Camel's Hair is a natural fiber from the camel. Camel hair can produce a variety of different coarseness of yarn. This fiber is a novelty fiber spun by hand-spinners.
words.name: Camel's Hair

words.def: Canvas is an extremely heavy-duty fabric used for making sails, tents, marquees, and other functions where sturdiness is required. It is also popularly used on fashion handbags.
words.name: Canvas

words.def: Canvas work is embroidery on canvas.
words.name: Canvas work

words.def: Carding is the processing of brushing raw or washed fibers to prepare them as textiles.
words.name: Carding

words.def: A carpet is any loom-woven, felted textile or grass floor covering.
words.name: Carpet

words.def: Cashmere is wool from the Cashmere goat.
words.name: Cashmere

words.def: Cellulose; this fiber processed to make cellophane and rayon, and more recently Modal, a textile derived from beechwood cellulose.
words.name: Cellulose

words.def: Cheesecloth is a loosewoven cotton cloth, such as is used in pressing cheese curds.
words.name: Cheesecloth

words.def: Chiffon is a sheer fabric made of silk or rayon.
words.name: Chiffon

words.def: Chino cloth is a kind of twill fabric, usually made primarily from cotton.
words.name: Chino cloth

words.def: Chintz is calico cloth printed with flowers and other devices in different colors. It was originally of Eastern manufacture.
words.name: Chintz

words.def: Coir is a coarse fibre extracted from the fibrous outer shell of a coconut.
words.name: Coir

words.def: Colors that will bleed or fade very easily from washing. Specifically, a textile's ability to maintain its color without running or fading.
words.name: Colorfast (Colourfast)

words.def: Cord is twisted fibre, usually intermediate between rope and string. It is also used as a shortened form of corduroy.
words.name: Cord

words.def: Corduroy is a durable cloth.
words.name: Corduroy

words.def: Cotton is a soft fibre that grows around the seeds of the cotton plant, a shrub native to the tropical and subtropical regions of both the Old World and the New World. The fibre is most often spun into thread and used to make a soft, breathable textile.
words.name: Cotton

words.def: Crash is a rough fabric made from yarns that are usually undyed. The coarsest type is called Russian crash. Linen is generally used for the warp yarn, while linen and jute are used for the filler.
words.name: Crash

words.def: Crepe is a silk fabric of a gauzy texture, having a peculiar crisp or crimpy appearance.
words.name: Crepe

words.def: Crazy quilting is the textile art of patchworking.
words.name: Crazy quilt

words.def: Crinoline was originally a stiff fabric with a weft of horse-hair and a warp of cotton or linen thread. The fabric first appeared around 1830.
words.name: Crinoline

words.def: Cross-stitch is a popular form of counted-thread embroidery in which X-shaped stitches are used to form a picture.
words.name: Cross-stitch

words.def: The process of creating fabric from a length of cord, yarn, or thread with a hooked tool.
words.name: Crochet

words.def: A crochet hook is a type of needle, usually with a hook at one end, used to draw thread through knotted loops.
words.name: Crochet hook

words.def: The cro-hook is a special double-ended crochet hook used to make double-sided crochet. Because the hook has two ends, two colours of thread can be handled at once and freely interchanged.
words.name: Cro-hook

words.def: Damask is a fabric of silk, wool, linen, cotton, or synthetic fibers, with a pattern formed by weaving. Today, it generally denotes a linen texture richly figured in the weaving with flowers, fruit, forms of animal life, and other types of ornament.
words.name: Damask

words.def: A darning mushroom is a tool which can be used for darning clothes, particularly socks. The sock can be stretched over the top of the (curved) mushroom, and gathered tightly around the stalk.
words.name: Darning mushroom

words.def: Denim denotes a rugged cotton twill textile.
words.name: Denim

words.def: Dimity is a lightweight, sheer cotton fabric having at least two warp threads thrown into relief to form fine cords.
words.name: Dimity

words.def: Dobby loom is a loom in which each harness can be manipulated individually. This is in contrast to a treadle loom, where the harnesses are attached to a number of different treadles depending on the weave structure.
words.name: Dobby loom

words.def: Double weave is a type of advanced weave. It is done by interlacing two or more sets of warps with two or more sets of filling yarns.
words.name: Double weave

words.def: Dowlas is the name given to a plain cloth, similar to sheeting, but usually coarser.
words.name: Dowlas

words.def: how durable a fabric or yarn is.
words.name: Durability

words.def: Dye is used to color fabric. There are two main types: Natural dyes and synthetic dyes. The process is called dyeing.
words.name: Dyes

words.def: Dye lot is a number that identifies yarns dyed in the same vat at the same time. Subtle differences can appear between different batches of the same color yarn from the same manufacturer.
words.name: Dye lot

words.def: Elasticity
words.name: Elasticity

words.def: Embroidery is an ancient variety of decorative needlework in which designs and pictures are created by stitching strands of some material on to a layer of another material. See also: Machine embroidery.
words.name: Embroidery

words.def: Ends per inch like Threads per inch is a measure of the coarseness or fineness of fabric, displaying the number of (warp) threads per inch of woven fabric.
words.name: Ends per inch (EPI)

words.def: A type of velvet fabric woven on a wire loom or épinglé loom. The épinglé velvet is notable in that both a loop pile and a cut pile can be integrated into the same fabric. The art of épinglé weaving in Europe originated from Lucca (Italy) and later came to Venice and Genua, which is where the term Genua velvet comes from. The technique of épinglé weaving is still used today in the Flemish region of Kortrijk and Waregem. The fabric finds it application mostly in upholstery, although in medieval times it was used as apparel for princes and kings as well as for bishops, cardinals, and the Pope.
words.name: Epinglé fabric

words.def: A kind of weaving machine whereby steel rods are inserted in a top shed which is formed over the bottom shed in which the weft is inserted. The steel rods are inserted into the fabric every second or third pick by a separate mechanism that is synchronised with the weaving motion. The same mechanism also extracts the rods from the fabric . If the rod carries a cutting blade at the tip the warps that are woven over the rods are cut, creating a cut pile effect. In case the rod has no blade, then the warp ends from a loop pile. Alternating cut and loop wires create cut and loop pile in the fabric. This weaving technology is used for weaving velvets for furnishing and apparel applications. These fabrics are known as 'moquette' or "épinglé' fabrics. This kind of weaving machine is also used for weaving carpets where it is known as a 'Wilton loom'.
words.name: Epinglé loom

words.def: Even-weave or evenweave fabric is used in counted-thread embroidery and is characterized by Warp and weft threads of the same size.
words.name: Even-weave

words.def: Grommets and eyelets are metal, plastic, or rubber rings that are inserted into a hole made through another material. They may be used to reinforce the hole, to shield something from the sharp edges of the hole, or both.
words.name: Eyelet

words.def: Felt is a non-woven cloth that is produced by matting, condensing and pressing fibers. The fibers form the structure of the fabric.
words.name: Felt

words.def: The process of making felt is called felting.
words.name: Felting

words.def: Fiber or fibre (see spelling differences) is a class of materials that are continuous filaments or are in discrete elongated pieces, similar to pieces of thread. Fibers are often used in the manufacture of other materials. They can be spun into filaments, thread, or rope. They can be used as a component of composite materials. They can also be matted into sheets to make products such as paper or felt.
words.name: Fiber

words.def: A filament is a fine, thinly spun thread, fiber, or wire.
words.name: Filament

words.def: See Weft
words.name: Filling

words.def: Finishing refers to any process performed on yarn or fabric after weaving to improve the look, performance, or "hand" (feel) of the finished textile.[3]
words.name: Finishing

words.def: Fishnet is a material with an open, diamond shaped knit.
words.name: Fishnet

words.def: Flannel is a cloth that is commonly used to make clothing and bedsheets. It is usually made from either wool, wool and cotton, or wool and synthetic fabric.
words.name: Flannel

words.def: Flax fiber is soft, lustrous and flexible. It is stronger than cotton fiber but less elastic. The best grades are used for linen fabrics such as damasks, lace and sheeting. Coarser grades are used for the manufacturing of twine and rope.
words.name: Flax

words.def: Frieze is a coarse woollen cloth with a nap on one side, that was raised by scrubbing it to raise curls of fibre (French: frisé). In the 19th century rough cheap frieze was made of wool mixed with shoddy (see Shoddy).
words.name: Frieze

words.def: Fulling is a step in clothmaking which involves the cleansing of cloth (particularly wool) to get rid of oils, dirt, and other impurities.
words.name: Fulling

words.def: A type of heavy twilled woven cotton fabrics, chiefly prepared for menswear. Usually dyed in a dark shade. Declined in popularity from 1813, being replaced by harder wearing and better quality wool cloths.
words.name: Fustian

words.def: Gabardine is a tough, tightly woven fabric often used to make suits, overcoats and trousers. The fibre used to make the fabric is traditionally worsted (a woolen yarn), but may also be cotton, synthetic or mixed. The fabric is smooth on one side and has a diagonally ribbed surface on the other.
words.name: Gabardine

words.def: A gauge is a set number of rows per inch (in knitting) or the thread-count of a woven fabric that helps the knitter determine whether they have the right size knitting needles or a weaver if the cloth is tight enough.
words.name: Gauge

words.def: Gante is a cloth made from cotton or tow warp and jute weft. It is largely used for bags for sugar and similar material, and has the appearance of a fine hessian cloth.
words.name: Gante

words.def: Gauze is a very light, sheer, fine woven fabric.
words.name: Gauze

words.def: A type of velvet where in Jacquard patterns are woven into the ground fabric and where the pile is made of a combination of cut and uncut (loop) pile. This fabric is also known as Venetian velvet, or more generally, as épinglé velvet. In the actual terminology of furnishing fabrics it is mostly named with its French name "velours de Gênes".
words.name: Genova velvet

words.def: A geotextile is a synthetic permeable textile.
words.name: Geotextile

words.def: Gingham is a fabric made from dyed cotton yarn.
words.name: Gingham

words.def: Fiberglass is material made from extremely fine fibers of glass. It is widely used in the manufacture of insulation and textiles.
words.name: Glass fiber (fibre)

words.def: A gossamer is a very light, sheer, gauze-like fabric, popular for white wedding dresses and decorations.
words.name: Gossamer

words.def: Grogram is a coarse fabric of silk mixed with wool or with mohair and often stiffened with gum. It also is known as Grosgrain.
words.name: Grogram

words.def: Common component of a loom used to separate warp threads for passage of the weft. Commonly made of cord or wire.
words.name: Heddle

words.def: To hem a piece of cloth (in sewing), a garment worker folds up a cut edge, folds it up again, and then sews it down. The process of hemming thus completely encloses the cut edge in cloth, so that it cannot ravel.
words.name: Hem

words.def: The main uses of hemp fibre are rope, sacking, carpet, nets and webbing. Hemp is also being used in increasing quantities in paper manufacturing. The cellulose content is about 70%.
words.name: Hemp

words.def: Huckaback is a type of coarse absorbent cotton or linen fabric used for making towels.[4]
words.name: Huckaback

words.def: Ikat is a style of weaving that uses a tie-dye process on either the warp or weft before the threads are woven to create a pattern or design. A Double Ikat is when both the warp and the weft are tie-dyed before weaving.
words.name: Ikat

words.def: Imberline is a woven fabric with various colored stripes in the warp, often separated by gold thread. The fabric is often used in upholstery and drapery manufacture.
words.name: Imberline

words.def: Intarsia is a knitting technique used to create patterns with multiple colours.
words.name: Intarsia

words.def: A type of material used on the unseen or "wrong" side of fabrics in sewing.
words.name: Interfacing

words.def: Jacquard
words.name: Jacquard

words.def: The Jacquard loom was the first machine to use punched cards. It uses punched cards to control the pattern being woven. It is a form of dobby loom, where individual harnesses can be raised and lowered independently.
words.name: Jacquard loom

words.def: Jamdani is a kind of fine cloth made in Bangladesh.
words.name: Jamdani

words.def: Jute is a long, soft, shiny plant fibre that can be spun into coarse, strong threads.
words.name: Jute

words.def: Knitting is the Process of inter-looping of yarns or inter-meshing of loops
words.name: Knitting

words.def: Knit fabrics are fabrics that were produced through the process of knitting.
words.name: Knit fabrics

words.def: A knitting needle gauge is used to determine the size of a knitting needle. Some also double for crochet hooks. Most needles come with the size written on the needle, but many needles (like double-pointed needles) tend to not be labeled. Also, with wear and time the label often wears off.
words.name: Knitting needle gauge

words.def: Lace-making is an ancient craft. A lace fabric is lightweight openwork fabric, patterned, either by machine or by hand, with open holes in the work. The holes can be formed via removal of threads or cloth from a previously woven fabric, but more often lace is built up from a single thread and the open spaces are created as part of the lace fabric.
words.name: Lace

words.def: Lamé is a type of brocaded clothing fabric with inwoven metal threads, typically of gold or silver, giving it a metallic sheen.
words.name: Lamé

words.def: Lawn is a fine linen or cotton cloth.
words.name: Lawn

words.def: Linen is a material made from the fibers of the flax plant. Linen produced in Ireland is called Irish linen. Linens are fabric household goods, such as pillowcases and towels.
words.name: Linen

words.def: Lining
words.name: Lining

words.def: Loden is water-resistant material for clothing made from sheep wool.
words.name: Loden

words.def: The Loom is a machine used for weaving fabric.
words.name: Loom

words.def: Lucet is a method of cordmaking or braiding which is believed to date back to the Viking age. Lucet cord is square, strong, and slightly springy. It closely resembles knitted I-cord or the cord produced on a knitting spool. Lucet cord is formed by a series of loops, and will therefore unravel if cut.
words.name: Lucet

words.def: Macrame or macramé is a form of textile-making using knotting rather than weaving or knitting. Its primary knots are the square knot and forms of hitching (full hitch and double half hitches).
words.name: Macramé

words.def: Mercerization is a treatment for cotton fabric and thread mostly employed to give cotton a lustrous appearance.
words.name: Mercerized cotton

words.def: Merino is the Spanish name for a breed of sheep, and hence applied to a woolen fabric.
words.name: Merino

words.def: A mesh is similar to fabric or a web in that it has many connected or weaved pieces. In clothing, a mesh is often defined as fabric that has a large number of closely spaced holes, such as is common practice for modern sports jerseys.
words.name: Mesh

words.def: Metallic fibers are fibers used in textiles which are either composed of metal, or fibers of other materials with a metal coating.
words.name: Metallic fiber (fibre)

words.def: Fibres with strands thinner than one denier. Fabrics made with microfibres are exceptionally soft and hold their shape well.
words.name: Microfibre (fiber)

words.def: Millinery is women's hats and other articles sold by a milliner, or the profession or business of designing, making, or selling hats for women.
words.name: Millinery

words.def: Mockado is a woollen pile fabric made in imitation of silk velvet.[5][6][7]
words.name: Mocado

words.def: Modal is a cellulose fiber made by spinning reconstituted cellulose from beech trees.
words.name: Modal

words.def: Mohair is a silk-like fabric made from the hair of the Angora goat. It is durable, light and warm, although some people find it uncomfortably itchy.
words.name: Mohair

words.def: Fibrous woollen material generated from waste fabric, particularly tightly woven cloths and rags. See also: shoddy.
words.name: Mungo

words.def: Muslin is a type of finely woven cotton fabric, introduced to Europe from the Middle East in the 17th century. It was named for the city where it was first made, Mosul in what is now Iraq.
words.name: Muslin

words.def: Nainsook is a fine, soft muslin fabric, often used to make babies clothing.
words.name: Nainsook

words.def: Nap is the raised surface of certain cloth, such as flannel.
words.name: Nap

words.def: Needlepoint is a form of canvas work created on a mesh canvas. The stitching threads used may be wool, silk, or rarely cotton. Stitches may be plain, covering just one mesh intersection with a single orientation, or fancy, such as Bargello. Plain stitches, known as Tent stitches, may be worked as basketweave or half cross.
words.name: Needlepoint

words.def: Needlework is another term for the handicraft of decorative sewing and textile arts. Anything that uses a needle for construction can be called needlework.
words.name: Needlework

words.def: Net is a device made by fibers woven in a grid-like structure, as in fishing net, a soccer goal, a butterfly net, or the court divider in tennis
words.name: Net

words.def: Non-woven textiles are those which are neither woven nor knit, for example felt. Non-wovens are typically not strong (unless reinforced by a backing), and do not stretch. They are cheap to manufacture.
words.name: Nonwoven fabric

words.def: Novelty yarn
words.name: Novelty yarn

words.def: Nylon is a synthetic polymer, a plastic. Nylon fibres are used to make many synthetic fabrics and women's stockings.
words.name: Nylon

words.def: Oil cloth was, traditionally, heavy cotton or linen cloth with a linseed oil coating: it was semi-waterproof. The most familiar use was for brightly printed kitchen tablecloths. Dull-colored oilcloth was used for bedrolls, sou'westers, and tents. By the late 1950s, oilcloth became a synonym for vinyl (polyvinyl chloride) bonded to either a flanneled cloth or a printed vinyl with a synthetic non-woven backing.
words.name: Oil cloth

words.def: Organdy or organdie is the sheerest cotton cloth made. Combed yarns contribute to its appearance. Its sheerness and crispness are the result of an acid finish on greige (unbleached) lawn goods. Because of its stiffness and fiber content, it is very prone to wrinkling.
words.name: Organdy

words.def: Organza is a thin, plain weave, sheer fabric traditionally made from silk, the continuous filament of silkworms. Nowadays, though many organzas are woven with synthetic filament fibers such as polyester or nylon, the most luxurious organzas are still woven in silk.
words.name: Organza

words.def: Paisley is a droplet-shaped vegetal motif, similar to half of the T'ai Chi symbol, the Indian bodhi tree leaf, or the mango tree. The design originated in India and spread to Scotland when British soldiers brought home cashmere shawls.
words.name: Paisley

words.def: Patchwork is a form of needlework or craft that involves sewing together small pieces of fabric and stitching them together into a larger design, which is then usually quilted, or else tied together with pieces of yarn at regular intervals, a practice known as tying. Patchwork is traditionally 'pieced' by hand, but modern quiltmakers often use a sewing machine instead.
words.name: Patchwork

words.def: Percale refers to a closely woven, high thread count, cotton fabric often used for sheets and clothing.
words.name: Percale

words.def: Persian weave is a method of weave used in jewelry and other art forms.
words.name: Persian weave

words.def: Pile knit
words.name: Pile knit

words.def: Pile weave
words.name: Pile weave

words.def: A steel rod which is inserted in between the base fabric and the pile ends in a pile fabric woven on a wire loom or épinglé loom. The height and thickness of the rod determine the size of the loop. A pile wire can be a simple rod - in which case the pile yarns will form a 'loop' pile. If the pile wire is equipped with a blade holder and cutting blade at the tip it will cut the pile loops during extraction thus producing cut pile.
words.name: Pile Wire

words.def: Pill
words.name: Pill

words.def: From a Scots language word meaning blanket, plaid usually referring to patterned woollen cloth otherwise known as tartan.
words.name: Plaid

words.def: Plain weave
words.name: Plain weave

words.def: Plied yarn is yarn that has been plied, with the process called plying.
words.name: Plied yarn

words.def: Plush is a fabric having a cut nap or pile the same as fustian or velvet.
words.name: Plush

words.def: Polyester is a synthetic fiber
words.name: Polyester

words.def: Poplin is a heavy, durable fabric that has a ribbed appearance. It is made with wool, cotton, silk, rayon, or any mixture of these. The ribs run across the fabric from selvage to selvage. They are formed by using coarse filling yarns in a plain weave.
words.name: Poplin

words.def: a commonly used stitch in knitting
words.name: Purl stitch

words.def: Qalamkari is a type of hand-painted or block-printed textile, produced in various places in India.
words.name: Qalamkari

words.def: Qiviut is the wool of the musk ox.
words.name: Qiviut

words.def: Quilting is a method of sewing or tying two layers of cloth with a layer of insulating batting in between. A bed covering or similar large rectangular piece of quilting work is called a quilt.
words.name: Quilt

words.def: Rayon is a transparent fibre made of processed cellulose. Cellulose fibres from wood or cotton are dissolved in alkali to make a solution called viscose, which is then extruded through a nozzle, or spinneret, into an acid bath to reconvert the viscose into cellulose. A similar process, using a slit instead of a hole, is used to make cellophane.
words.name: Rayon

words.def: Rib knit
words.name: Rib knit

words.def: Rib weave
words.name: Rib weave

words.def: A rolag is a loose woolen roll of fibers that results from using handcards.
words.name: Rolag

words.def: A roving is a long rope of fibers where all of the fibers are going parallel to the roving.
words.name: Roving

words.def: A rug is a form of carpet. It is usually smaller than a carpet. See also: rug making
words.name: Rug

words.def: Sailcloth
words.name: Sailcloth

words.def: Sateen is a fabric formed with a satin weave where the floats are perpendicular to the selvage of the goods.
words.name: Sateen

words.def: A Satin is a cloth that typically has a glossy surface and a dull back. It is formed by a sequence of broken twill floats in either the warp or weft system, which respectively identify the goods as either a satin or a sateen.
words.name: Satin

words.def: A satin is a broken twill weaving technique that forms floats on one side of the fabric. If a satin is woven with the floats parallel to the selvedge of the goods, the corresponding fabric is termed a "satin." If the floats are perpendicular to the selvedge of the goods, the fabric is termed a 'sateen.'"
words.name: Satin weave

words.def: A seam, in sewing, is the line where two pieces of fabric are held together by thread.
words.name: Seam

words.def: A seam ripper is a small tool used for unpicking stitches.
words.name: Seam ripper

words.def: The woven edge portion of a fabric parallel to the warp is called selvage.
words.name: Selvage or Selvedge

words.def: Serge is a type of twill fabric that has diagonal lines or ridges on both sides, made with a two-up, two-down weave. The worsted variety is used in making military uniforms, suits, great and trench coats. Its counterpart, silk serge, is used for linings. French serge is a softer, finer variety. The word is also used for a high quality woolen woven.
words.name: Serge

words.def: Serging is the binding off of an edge of cloth.
words.name: Serging

words.def: Sewing is an ancient craft involving the stitching of cloth, leather, animal skins, furs, or other materials, using needle and thread. Its use is nearly universal among human populations and dates back to Paleolithic times (30,000 BC). Sewing predates the weaving of cloth.
words.name: Sewing

words.def: Shag (fabric) is typically used to make a deep-pile carpets. This is the oldest use of the term. Shag carpet is sometimes evoked as an example of the aesthetic from the culture of the U.S. 1970s. Also used to make carpets for mariners.
words.name: Shag

words.def: In weaving, the shed is the gap between yarns on a loom when one or more, but not all, of the harnesses are raised.
words.name: Shed

words.def: Sheer is a semi-transparent and flimsy cloth.
words.name: Sheer

words.def: Recycled or remanufactured wool. Historically generated from loosely woven materials. Benjamin Law invented shoddy and mungo, as such, in England in 1813. He was the first to organise, on a larger scale, the activity of taking old clothes and grinding them down into a fibrous state that could be re-spun into yarn. The shoddy industry was centred on the towns of Batley, Morley, Dewsbury and Ossett in West Yorkshire, and concentrated on the recovery of wool from rags. The importance of the industry can be gauged by the fact that even in 1860 the town of Batley was producing over 7000 tonnes of shoddy. At the time there were 80 firms employing a total of 550 people sorting the rags. These were then sold to shoddy manufacturers of which there were about 130 in the West Riding. Shoddy is inferior to the original wool; "shoddy" has come to mean "of poor quality" in general (not related to clothing), and the original meaning is largely obsolete.
words.name: Shoddy

words.def: The opal effect achieved on a fabric by dyeing the warp and weft threads different colours. The yarns are dyed first and then woven. When looking at the fabric from various angles it appears to alter in colour, this is more obvious in lustrous fabrics and more so in certain types of weaves.
words.name: Shot

words.def: A shuttle in weaving is a device used with a loom that is thrown or passed back and forth between the threads of the warp to weave in the weft.
words.name: Shuttle

words.def: Silk is a natural protein fiber that can be woven into textiles. It is obtained from the cocoon of the silkworm larva, in the process known as sericulture, which kills the larvae. The shimmering appearance for which it is prized comes from the fibre's triangular prism-like structure, which allows silk cloth to refract incoming light at different angles.
words.name: Silk

words.def: Sisal or sisal hemp is an agave Agave sisalana that yields a stiff fiber used in making rope. (The term may refer either to the plant or the fiber, depending on context.) It is not really a variety of hemp, but named so because hemp was for centuries a major source for fiber, so other fibers were sometimes named after it.
words.name: Sisal

words.def: Skein is when a length of yarn is bundled in a loose roll rather than put on a cone (as you would purchase from store)- usually done if yarn is going to a dye vat or needs a treatment in a manufacturing/knitting mill environment.
words.name: Skein

words.def: Solution-dyed
words.name: Solution-dyed

words.def: Spandex or elastane is a synthetic fiber known for its exceptional elasticity (stretchability). It is stronger and more durable than rubber, its major plant competitor. It was invented in 1959 by DuPont, and when first introduced it revolutionized many areas of the clothing industry.
words.name: Spandex fiber

words.def: Spinning is the process of creating yarn (or thread, rope, cable) from various raw fiber materials.
words.name: Spinning

words.def: Spread Tow Fabrics is a type of lightweight fabric. Its production involves the steps of spreading a tow of higher count, e.g. 12k, into thin-and-wide spread tow tape (STT) and weaving them into a lightweight fabric by employing the novel tape-weaving technique.
words.name: Spread Tow Fabrics

words.def: Staple is the raw material, or its length and quality, of fiber from which textiles are made.
words.name: Staple

words.def: A stitch is a single turn or loop of the thread or yarn in sewing, knitting, and embroidery.[8]
words.name: Stitch

words.def: Stuff is a coarse cloth, sometimes made with a linen warp and worsted weft.
words.name: Stuff

words.def: The Super grading system is used to grade the quality of wool fabric. The higher the number, the more yarn is packed in per square inch, therefore all things being equal a super 120s yarn is better than super 100s.
words.name: Super

words.def: Tablet weaving is a process of weaving where tablets, also called 'cards', are used to create the shed that the weft is passed through. It is generally used to make narrow work such as belts or straps.
words.name: Tablet weaving

words.def: Tactel is the brand name of a man-made fibre made from nylon.
words.name: Tactel

words.def: Taffeta is a type of fabric, often used for fancy dresses.
words.name: Taffeta

words.def: Tapestry is a form of textile art. It is woven by hand on a weaving-loom. The chain thread is the carrier in which the coloured striking thread is woven. In this way, a colourful pattern or image is created. Most weavers use a naturally based chain thread made out of linen or wool. The striking threads can be made out of silk, wool, gold or silver, but can also be made out of any form of textile.
words.name: Tapestry

words.def: Tarlatan (alt. sp. tarlaton) is a starched, open-weave fabric, much like cheese cloth. It is used to wipe the ink off a plate during the intaglio inking process. The open weave allows for the tarlatan to pick up a large quantity of ink. The stiffness imparted by the starch helps prevent the fabric from taking the ink out of the incised lines.
words.name: Tarlatan

words.def: A tassel is a ball-shaped bunch of plaited or otherwise entangled threads from which at one end protrudes a cord on which the tassel is hung, and which may have loose, dangling threads at the other end.
words.name: Tassel

words.def: Tatting is a technique for handcrafting lace that can be documented approximately to the early 19th century.
words.name: Tatting

words.def: Terry cloth is a type of cloth with loops sticking out. Most bath towels are examples of Terry cloth.
words.name: Terry cloth

words.def: A thimble is a protective shield worn on the finger or thumb.
words.name: Thimble

words.def: Threads per inch is the measurement of the number of threads per inch of material, such as fabric, or metal in the case of screws and bolts.
words.name: Threads per inch (TPI)

words.def: The thread count is the number of warp threads per inch plus the number of weft threads.
words.name: Thread count

words.def: Tissue is a fine woven fabric or gauze.
words.name: Tissue

words.def: Trim or trimming in clothing and home decorating is applied ornament such as gimp, passementerie, ribbon, ruffles, or, as a verb, to apply such ornament.
words.name: Trim

words.def: Tulle is a netting, which is often starched, made of various fibers, including silk, nylon, and rayon, that is most commonly used for veils, gowns (particularly wedding gowns) and ballet tutus.
words.name: Tulle

words.def: Tweed is a type of fabric using the twill weave.
words.name: Tweed

words.def: Twill tape is a flat twill-woven ribbon of cotton, linen, polyester, or wool.
words.name: Twill tape

words.def: Twill is a type of fabric woven with a pattern of diagonal parallel ribs. It is made by passing the weft threads over one warp thread and then under two or more warp threads. Examples of twill fabric are gabardine, tweed and serge.
words.name: Twill weave

words.def: Velour is a textile, a knitted counterpart of velvet.
words.name: Velour

words.def: Velvet is a type of tufted fabric in which the cut threads are very evenly distributed, with a short dense pile, giving it its distinct feel. Velvet can be made from any fiber. It is woven on a special loom that weaves two piece of velvet at the same time. The two pieces are then cut apart and the two lengths of fabric are wound on separate take-up rolls.
words.name: Velvet

words.def: Velveteen is a cotton cloth made in imitation of velvet. The term is sometimes applied to a mixture of silk and cotton. Some velveteens are a kind of fustian, having a rib of velvet pile alternating with a plain depression. The velveteen, trade varies a good deal with the fashions that control the production of velvet.
words.name: Velveteen

words.def: Viscose is an artificial cellulose-based polymer, sometimes used as a synonym for Rayon
words.name: Viscose

words.def: The warp is the set of lengthwise threads attached to a loom before weaving begins, and through which the weft is woven.
words.name: Warp

words.def: Warp knit
words.name: Warp knit

words.def: Waterproof
words.name: Waterproof

words.def: Water repellent
words.name: Water repellent

words.def: Weaving is an ancient textile art and craft that involves placing two sets of threads or yarn made of fibre called the warp and weft of the loom and turning them into cloth. This cloth can be plain (in one color or a simple pattern), or it can be woven in decorative or artistic designs, including tapestries.
words.name: Weaving

words.def: The weft is the yarn that is woven back and forth through the warp to make cloth.
words.name: Weft

words.def: Weft knit
words.name: Weft knit

words.def: Wilton carpet is produced on a specific type of weaving machine called wire loom. Wilton carpets are pile carpets whereby the pile is formed by inserting steel rods in the pile warps of the fabric. After extraction of the rods the pile is looped (in case straight wires have been used) or cut (in case cutting wires are used). Wilton carpet is generally considered as high quality and is used for heavy duty applications.
words.name: Wilton Carpet

words.def: Weaving machine for pile fabrics or velvets whereby the pile is made by weaving steel rods or wires into the fabrics. When the wires are extracted the warp ends that have been woven over the wires remain as loops on top of the fabric or will form cut pile if the wire is equipped with a cutting blade. This technique is also known as "épinglé weaving". A wire loom in a much wider version (up to 5 meters of width) and in heavier construction is used for the manufacturing of carpets is called a "WILTON" loom, and the carpets made on such a loom are known as "Wilton Carpets"
words.name: Wire loom,

words.def: The woof is the same thing as the weft.
words.name: Woof

words.def: Wool is the fiber derived from the hair of domesticated animals, usually sheep.
words.name: Wool

words.def: Woolen or woollen is the name of a yarn and cloth usually made from wool.
words.name: Woolen

words.def: Worsted is the name of a yarn and cloth usually made from wool. The yarn is well twisted and spun of long staple wool (though nowadays also medium and short fibres are used). The wool is combed so that the fibres lie parallel.
words.name: Worsted fabric

words.def: A woven fabric is a cloth formed by weaving. It only stretches in the bias directions (between the warp and weft directions), unless the threads are elastic. Woven cloth usually frays at the edges, unless measures are taken to counter this, such as the use of pinking shears or hemming.
words.name: Woven fabric

words.def: Yarn is a long continuous length of interlocked fibers, suitable for use in the production of textiles, sewing, crocheting, knitting, weaving and ropemaking. Yarn can be made from any number of synthetic or natural fibers.
words.name: Yarn

words.def: Zibeline is a thick, soft fabric with a long nap.
words.name: Zibeline
